html:
Etymology[edit]

From ex- +‎ currō.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ekˈskur.roː/, [ɛkˈskʊr.roː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ekˈskur.ro/, [ɛkˈskur.rɔ]

Verb[edit]

excurrō (present infinitive excurrere, perfect active excurrī or excucurrī, supine excursum); third conjugation

  1. I run out
  2. I sally forth
  3. I project, extend

Derived terms[edit]

  • excursiō
  • excursō
  • excursor
  • excursus
  • superexcurrō

Related terms[edit]

  • excursātiō
  • excursātor

Descendants[edit]

  • Asturian: escorrer
  • Catalan: escórrer
  • English: excur
  • Friuian: scori
  • Galician: escorrer
  • Italian: scorrere
  • Occitan: escórrer
  • Old Spanish: escorrer
  • Portuguese: escorrer
  • Romanian: scure, scurge
  • Sicilian: scùrriri
  • Spanish: escurrir

References[edit]

  • excurro in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • excurro in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • excurro in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • a peninsula projects into the sea: paeninsula in mare excurrit, procurrit
    • to make a pleasure-trip into the country: rus excurrere
